ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Stever sensei had in-person lectures for those of us willing and able to attend. There was also discussion 'clinic' with a TF once a week for speaking and reading practice.
Optional in-person seminar for those on campus

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic Japanese grammar, writing, and conversational courses.

All hiragana and katakana characters, around 75 kanji. Introductions and useful phrases, describing family, directions, locations, talking about yourself, asking questions, adjectives and descriptions, counting, some superficial cultural exposure.
Basic communication in Japanese in topics like food, family, and hobbies, and reading and writing in Hiragana, Katakana, and some Kanji.
Basic Japanese vocabulary, grammar, and a little bit of culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Pretty much everything. It was a very well organized course. 
Weaknesses: If you take the course online and not everyone's mic is muted during conversation it can be hard to hear or ask questions to the professor.

The constant engagement is very good for reinforcing the language and writing systems. Homework exercises were actually useful and not redundant. The clinic section is also very good because you get to practice speaking and can learn more 'actual' Japanese rather than just formal stuff.

Could be interesting to include more videos and listening to native speakers. There was some of this and obviously you won't understand much at L1, but listening to actual conversational Japanese rather than textbook conversations designed for learners is helpful.

Strengths: Good pacing, reasonable workload.
Weaknesses: lots of printed-out assignments. For virtual learning, this isn't great, and investment in a tablet for note writing purposes is recommended.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This was the only class that actually had a functional hybrid learning system, where we had mixed in-person and remote attendance for whoever was on campus. It was very useful in engaging with the class and I definitely got to know my classmates very well through meeting them in-person. 

I think some of the homework and tests could be better suited for online work, especially because on-campus people didn't have access to printers for the first couple of weeks. This is pretty minor though, and hopefully won't be required soon.
Keeping the video and microphone on were successful practices for me, since that kept me focused. Asking questions to each student turn by turn during class has also helped with my engagement.

We had a mix of in-person and online students in my lecture, but we were able to work together pretty well over Zoom, and was able to form conversation groups with breakout rooms. Doing the course online didn't have a significant impact on my ability to participate in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Stever sensei makes this course so engaging and enjoyable!

Absolutely. Very good introduction to an amazing language and you will be genuinely surprised at how quickly you pick up reading and writing Japanese. Even if you don't speak/read/write Mandarin this is a very accessible class and you will have no problems with reading and writing the scripts. Everyone I've spoken to loved this course. If you're thinking about Japanese for your language requirement or even just for fun, DO IT.

If you're new to the language and are really interested in learning it, I would recommend this course. In one semester, you learn two whole writing systems and some of the third, as well as enough grammar to maintain a basic conversation.
Yes, it is an excellent introduction to the Japanese language.
